newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatia's lending rate rises to 11.6 vs 10.8 pct.
newsitem.headline: Croatia's lending rate rises to 11.6 vs 10.8 pct.

text.p: Croatia's average lending rate rose to 11.6 percent on Thursday from 10.8 percent after more term settlements at higher rates.
The day's trade totalled 37 million kuna, some 30 million of which were fresh deals. The demand for another five million was not met as borrowers and lenders failed to agree on terms.
Interbank call money, stable at 10.5 percent, accounted for the bulk of transactions.
Banks extended two-week loans at 12 percent and one-month loans at 15 and 16 percent, the latter paid by a savings bank.
The banking sector made no fresh borrowings from the central bank today after repaying all but 18.6 million kuna in outstanding Lombard loans on Wednesday, a bank official said.
The central bank's kuna midrates for Friday firmed to 6.1249 against the dollar and eased to 3.5770 versus the mark. -- Metka Jelenc, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
